reviewText:
I don't even know where to start with this game. Don't go into it expecting a fast paced action rpg. This game is slow, but that pace is very intentional. It's the closest games have come to the writing level of books. Every character is so well written. Not only that but so many small actions have constantly growing consequences, hence the slow pace. It feels like a living, breathing world. The first act can drag a bit, but it's worth it to stick with it, because that drag is building a series of decisions that come back to haunt you toward the end. There's no good or evil, just consequences. Everyone has compelling motives, even the wild hunt. I've never had such an understanding and sense of duty when facing a final boss in a video game. This is, without a doubt, the best open world rpg of all time, and quite possibly the best epic told in video games. The characters are so endearing and interesting. Nothing is ever as it seems, and it creates a sense of ownership over your decisions. I never reloaded a save in order to keep a character alive or get some different outcome. Just buy it and play it. CD projeckt red is also an incredible developer, and, if anything, that should be rewarded with financial success. My favorite game of all time. Don't go in with preconceived notions of what an rpg is, or an action game, or a story based game. Understand the unparalleled scope and scale of this game, with a consistent high quality all around.
Now onto the dlc... I have never played a game story with this much depth, ever. Hearts of Stone could easily be analyzed like a classic novel. The depth and complexity of the themes it tackles are unparalleled in games. Then they throw in the best boss fights of the game, and new combat upgrades, and this little ten dollar expansion puts most fifty dollar ones to shame. That's all I will say without spoilers. If you own the witcher 3, Hearts of Stone is a must buy.
SPOILERS FOR HEARTS OF STONE
In classic Witcher fashion there are three acts to HoS. The first, the heist, establishes the wealth and rivalries between the wealthy novigradian families. The second is a wedding, showing the unity and possible financial troubles of two of these novigrad families, and then the final act deconstructs the marriage of Olgierd and his wife. The emotional journey this creates allows the writers to explore the theme of love in a way no other came can come close to. what other game, for an entire third, sends you to a wedding with no combat, and yet it becomes the most memorable part of the game. Finally, after helping Iris let go of her past by taking the rose (or not, you monster,) you confront Gaunter O' Dimm and have the option to also release Olgierd from the guilt of his past. In classic literature, specifically the heroes journey, the hero travels to hell, usually through a cave, to confront their fears and come out prepared for the final confrontation. Guess what the only way to get to the devil in order to free a mans soul is through? You guessed it, a cave. Gaunter has such depth he nearly overshadows Eredin. He mimicks the temptations of the devil to Christ in the wilderness, promising bread, armor (protection), and weapons (power). He then proceeds to claim that his bread will never run out (bread of life) and drink that will never run out (living water, or in this case vodka). He mirrors Christ until you realize it's a mockery, and he really is the devil. Geralt is able to take Olgierds debt, and cancel it in order to free his soul. The Witcher is all about reimagining famous tales, and CD Projeckt Red clearly couldn't help themselves. Finally at the end (if you save Olgierd) Geralt recieves Iris. As he takes it from Olgierds hand he cuts Olgierd. Olgierds wife, Iris, was plucked by the divorce rose given to her, and at the end of HoS Olgierd is cut by the sword Iris. There is so much depth that could easily go unoticed. The writing on display is unparalleled in games.

reviewText:
The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is a massive open world RPG that sets itself in a gritty, yet beautiful world influenced by Slavic and Norse mythology. I mean it's got 'Wild Hunt' in it's name. That says everything!

In The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt, you play as returning protagonist, Geralt of Rivia. A witcher who now seeks to move on in his life and continues his saga, going back home to Kaer Morhen. Settling in and finding peace wasn't the hard part. Facing a group of icy horsemen called the Wild Hunt willing to end his life while pursuing the emperor's runaway daughter is.

I don't even know where to start. The seamless and continuous world of Novigrad's cities, to the dangerous countrysides of Velen; also known as 'No Man's Land'. The seemingly endless number of quests to do, chasing down Witcher contracts and killing griffons, Ghouls, and other beasts that await your bloody death. Not to mention the amount of things to discover and explore when you're just roaming around on your horse, which I've found doing more than fast travelling, as this fantastical realm is one of the most beautiful I've ever seen.

Choices. It's a word that some games define it very well, like BioWare's Mass Effect and Dragon Age IPs. You get to choose what your character does, where they go, and so forth. Every choices makes a different in the world that affects someone. The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt has implemented this in an extraordinary way. Think about what would happen if you saved the lives of bandits in their camp, originally to have you killed. Will they continue raiding other nearby villages? Or will they be inevitably caught in their demise, killed by a feral beast that lurks around their camp? Every single one of your decisions affects something in this world. Whatever happens on the road is as you see, and it's not even scripted.

I ride on my horse from the rural hills of Velen, and into the city of Novigrad, finding monster nests, caves, thieves, wolves, and not to forget the men and women in distress when they're being attacked. These are just things along the way to a story quest that I follow, but end up getting lost in the world, wanting to explore it and choosing to help those in need. I don't even continue on to the story quest-- roaming a bit more of the areas around me, and occupying myself with the side quests.

The combat has been changed and it's almost completely different from the previous Witcher games in the series in terms of smoothness and fluidity. When I evade or roll out of my enemy's attacks, it all just flows. For your fights and encounters to go the way you want them to, you must time your parries and attacks correctly. Every time you execute an attack, the enemy may go into a flurry of attacks and stagger you, gaining the upper hand in the fight. Nevertheless, The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is a challenging game set out to kill you.

-     10 / 10

reviewText:
The Witcher 3 well deserves its title as Game of the Year. It's a massive game, with well-written character interaction and plot, and heapin' LOADS of content. To make the deal even better, its gameplay mechanics have been so drastically improved since the last two games, with combat and movement as a whole feeling a lot more flexible and responsive than it did in Assassin of Kings. Overall, it creates for a challenging and compelling package that'll keep you occupied for well over a month.

More specifically
Good stuff:
No shortage of options and content. You can play this game just about any way you like and succeed in fights, and as long as you pay attention to what's going on in combat, stick by some sort of principle when you engage in quest conversations, and not be afraid to explore, you will do great at this game.
Gorgeous. Not only is the graphical quality in this game potentially incredible, but it's very well-optimized once you get the right settings. Now, I'm a lazy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and just used GeForce experience to tweak the settings, but on that configuration there were barely any instances I had of frame dropping or slowdown. It's a beautifully optimized and stable game overall, with its most notable feature being how it streams loading as you travel. Artifacts such as hitching temporarily for loading, and even LOD models, are nigh invisible.
Massive and Engaging. Overall the whole game does a ton to successfully world-build itself, even without having to waste too many words on giving literally every single person dialogue (i.e. Oblivion or Skyrim). In particular, the city of Novigrad has to be one of the best designed locations I've seen in a game to date, almost feeling like a to-scale design of a whole city.
Best combat in the series. You're not going to run into the same sort of awkwardness that was present in Assassin of Kings - attack timings and hitboxes on stuff such as dodge-rolls feel spot-on and are natural to adapt to. Signs also feel much more organic to transition in and out of, and the aiming on thrown/ranged weapons is much smoother. Granted AoK could use mods to fix some of those issues, but this game manages quite well right out of the box. What also is very nice is how you can generally learn how an enemy looks, and from that, deduce the sort of battle tactics to take to counter that - For example, a human enemy's got a huge axe or hammer? Don't block, roll out of there! Or just do a quick attack to hit them mid-swing.
And if the game's base content wasn't enough, it has heaping loads of free DLC, which is almost unheard of nowadays. A good deal of it is cosmetics and alternate costumes for characters, but there is quite a bit of small side quests thrown in as well.
Also as an aside, gwent is way better than dice poker.
Bad Stuff:
Inverted Learning Curve. This problem plagues ALL of the Witcher games - the hardest content is always at the start, before you've had a chance to build up resources or experience to fight most enemies. Granted this has probably more to do with my playstyle than with the game itself to some degree (see extra tips), but yet it's still something that's gotten me on each of the games I played.
Not gamebreaking bugs, but weird bugs. You'll be sure to run into weird errata such as suddenly losing the ability to block, all fire disappearing from the game, or even getting an extreme close-up of the back of Geralt's head. Usually the bugs are fixable, at worst, by restarting the game, but it's still curious to end up in that sort of situation. Thankfully the game still is getting a stream of extra DLC and bugfixes at the moment, or so it seems.
Sometimes ambiguous dialog choices. With how important it is to take a stance concerning ingame characters and their opinions, having it a little unclear what Geralt might mean by the following line sometimes is a bit detrimental. Though sometimes the results are much funnier because of it (recalling: accidentally telling Roche ♥♥♥♥ you" right at the start of the 2nd game.)
Light on (Challenging) Fighting. Now

reviewText:
I am loving this game. Looks amazing, can't wait to see how they improve it.

The combat is suitably difficult, but once mastered is rewarding. You are punished for making mistakes, as it should be. Expect to die a lot, and save often.

Controlling Geralt, whather on the ground, in the water or on a horse can be quite challenging in small spaces. he has a turning circle, quite a large one for a man. Most of the areas are large enough so it doesn't matter but yeah, can be frustrating.

The story is lovely, although I feel like I'm rushing, so slowed down to take in the wonderful side quests. Very varied, never dull. World is huge, but admittedly a little smaller than I expected.

But yeah, buy it.

reviewText: This game is pretty damn cool. For one thing, it's HUGE, and there's so much to do and see. Yeah, you have a selection of main quests, but you never really feel rail-roaded into doing them, and you can pretty much go at your own pace, doing whatever you want. I find the combat nice and fast, and challenging enough, and would strongly recommend people don't use the locking system while attacking (it's a bit ♥♥♥♥♥). But overall I'm really enjoying the game and would highly recommend it. As with other Witcher games there's a good depth in choices, consequences, and characters that keep you engaged throughout. Certainly anyone wanting a deep RPG with Deus-Ex-like choices, and Age Of Amalur-like combat and cityscapes need look no further. It wouldn't surprise me if this became my game of the year (and we're only in May) - it's that good, and has mod support for later expansion. Don't let this one pass you by :)

reviewText:
First of all I had been looking forward to this game since its announcement. This probably is or is one of the best RPG games that I have played in some years. Some complain about how short it is but I completed the game in about 75 hours but to be honest with the enormous amount of in depth and intriguing side quests and Witcher contracts to be completed I don’t see how you can complete the game in such short hours and then complain about how short the game. The problem is your so excited to play the Witcher 3 you dash through the main quests. I do not recommend this as one problem is after you complete the main quests your stuck with a lot of side quest that you have no motivation to complete. Having said this is you complete lots of side quests along side the main quest line you will be levelling up and enjoying the experience much more and realising the game is as long as you make it.
This game should be tried by all it has amazing graphics, beautiful scenery and an enormous open world to explore. There are hundreds of small treasures and areas to explore that will require a Witchers touch. Plenty of NPC amazingly voiced to talk to. They all have their own personality which really brings the towns and cities alive. The customisation with your gear is vast and its all about learning along the way but upgrading and finding new gear is always the key in these type of RPG games. The new and improved combat can at times be a bit 'funky' to say the least but being such a customisable game and being an RPG open world something sometimes is going to bug out, but having said this the combat most of the time is flawless with devilish finishing moves and devastating signs.
One of the most important points for me being not only a open world free roam RPG but also the fact that this is a Witcher game is that dialogue, choices and relationships you build. The dialogue is brilliant with every NPC you talk to. You will make decisions which will affect your later decisions so be careful what you say. The choices you make via dialogue are truly game changing later on. For me the choices you make through dialogue should not affect your end result so dramatically it should be more what you do than what you say but this still adds a great feel to the game.  Relationships are a huge aspect of the Witcher games especially now that you lost lover Yen is back along with Ciri. But every person has a different level of humour and a different relationship with Geralt. Which is exactly what makes you feels the connection and build a rapport between you and other characters.
All in all this game really came out on top of the expectations. There are of course always some minor detail that can be polished but this is why we have updates to clear the slate of any problems that you find. But this game really has the lot excellent gameplay, Gorgeous graphics, brutal combat, amazingly voiced characters, brilliant story line and a huge world to explore.
I would definitely recommend this game. :)

reviewText:
It is a shining example of what RPGs should be: an experience that makes you believe that you’re truly part of a game’s world and that you have a very real stake in it. That’s exactly what Wild Hunt has achieved here. The Witcher 3 is a masterpiece, and in many respects simply one of the bests and most exciting game in recent years. It captivates players with artistic vision, a huge world and an epic story. The developers were not looking for cheap applause - game design is uncompromising, consistent, thoughtful and nuanced. There is no saving the world, here, no great evil force pervading the landscape, or a doomsday clock ticking down to inevitable destruction, with only you to stand in its way. The story of Wild Hunt is a personal one, set in a huge and unrelentingly beautiful world. The game is massive. This is in two ways - one of which is the scale of the map. It’s bigger than Skyrim’s world and after tens of hours you’ll have barely scratched the surface. It’s a beautiful world, too. You stumble in a beggar and a quest with a magnific and well built story starts  and then you realize that is just a SIDE quest, thats pretty much the quests in a nutshell: It is one better than another. Not only do you care about the characters and want to see how their stories end, but you want to scour every inch of The Witcher 3's glorious game world. It's a world you want to get lost in, a world where fast travel is an afterthought and a world you want to keep exploring in case there's something you've missed. The variety of quest is outstanding. It has to be given how many there are, but you can find yourself searching for a person of interest one minute, playing cards the next, then starring in a play soon after.

This is the new standard for open world role-playing games. There is no such thing as a perfect game, but The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt come as close to perfect as any RPG to date.

A monumental achievement of staggeringly aching beauty, the Witcher 3 stands proudly as one of the (if not the) greatest video game of all time, regardless of genre. Geralt's final, epic ride, is the high water-mark by which all future games will be judged and found lacking. Indeed, it's only disadvantage is that it completely ruins every other title on the market right now by nailing every single aspect of game design with almost supernatural clarity and perfection. If you play one video game in your life, make sure it's this one.

Quality like this doesn't tend to arrive until way later in a generation, so we doff our caps to the team at CDPR for breaking tradition to deliver one of the best RPGs we've ever played. Make some room on your hard drive and shelf, The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt deserves a permanent spot in your gaming library.

reviewText:
What can I say, what can I say. This is truly a masterpiece of a game, and I’m not referring to the rigged IGN reviews. This game is so rich in its story and open world. The fact that people say that the combat system is crap does the game no good. Yes I do agree that the combat system can be a spamathon sometimes but there is a deep and knowledgeable combat system in the sense of the oils and potions you brew in preparations to each fight. Each monster is truly unique and are even better if you are slightly under-levelled. Each huge monster that you face (which can occur in the wild) are like boss fights and you learn them. You learn how they attack, defend and ultimately what there weak to. There are only a handful of monsters the game tells you what they are weak to and you essentially wing it from there making the monster fights that little greater and much tenser. Now the quests, the main story line quests you could say drag on a fair bit in some cases but the game rewards you for the hardship you undertook. The characters are amazingly written and have there only unique quirks and great voice actors making them believable. Then there is Ciri, The star of the show you may say. Probably the most and believable character, and definitely the best wrote. I won’t spoil too much but the ending of this game is incredible. Secondary quests are also imaginatively written to the extremes of (Spoiler Alert!!!) a plot to kill the king which effects the games ending drastically. Of cause there will be fetch quests but that is the nature of RPGs.
In conclusion 10/10 would save Ciri again

Edit* Now having completed both DLCs i can firmly say that The Witcher 3 Wild Hunt is my favourite game of all time (Seriously you can check my profile desription if you wish) and i would easily reccomend this game to anyone in a heartbeat if they are prepared for the heatwarming yet dark tale that is The Witcher 3 Wild Hunt (And the DLCs)

reviewText:
(Since Witcher 3 is graphically demanding, I've provided a benchmark here.)
AMD FX 8120, GTX 770, 8 Gigs Ram (my specs, are in line with recommended specs)
With these specs I am able to run the game on HIGH settings with a few post-processing effects turned off (I get a steady 45-50 fps @ 1080p).  Turning off Hairworks will boost your fps.  For me, Hairworks on Geralt only used an extra 10 frames per second.

Even on High settings, this game looks amazing.  It must be fairly well optimized since I've seen no stutter in frames with such high quality textures, long draw distance, many NPCs, and lots of animated foliage.

(I use a Logitech F710.  Witcher 3 was designed for a gamepad.  No, that is not a betrayal to PC gamers.  Alternatives to KB&M have always been around.  The great thing about PC gaming is having many control options available.)
The control scheme is very similar to that of Witcher 2.  The only complaint I've had so far is that the movement (outside of combat) is a little clunky.  Sometimes it's difficult to get Geralt turned to face a certain direction (the horse is even less precise) but this is a very minor issue.  The swimming controls can be a bit frustrating until you get the hang of it.  Combat, however feels good.  It's been improved since Witcher 2.  I noticed that Geralt attacks with precision whichever enemy I point the control stick toward, allowing me to seamlessly dance from one enemy to the next, keeping them all in check (as you imagine an outnumbered master-swordsmen would fight).  It is essential to utilize all available combat mechanics in this game such as rolling, dodging, magic, and alchemy.  Unless you're playing of Easy, spamming only sword attacks won't work well.  Each enemy acts differently too making it rewarding to study their movements and learn how to react and exploit weaknesses.  The combat system is quite deep and makes you fight like a professional witcher.  (Geralt is not a damage absorbing demigod.)  It is also necessary to read up on beasts and monsters (in the glossary or found books) to learn about their strengths and weaknesses.  This is especially true for Witcher Contracts.

Crafting is now a big part of the game and everything you pick up can be broken down into crafting materials (junk now has a purpose).  Weapons and armor deteriorate with use and eventually need to be repaired.  This is not a tedious affair, though, since items degrade pretty slowly and you can always carry repair kits instead of finding a blacksmith or armorer.  You'll collect an entire library of diagrams for weapons, armor, potions, blade oils, bombs, etc.  Gathering ingredients is useful since every craftable item is integrated in a meaningful way.

The main map, mini map, quest log, and quest markers are all very useful and ensure that you won't feel lost (you can also turn off mini map markers).  I've yet to find a side quest that felt like padding or busy work.  In fact, most quests are complex and lengthy affairs (in a good way).  Leveling up and gaining abilities is unique (limited ability slots and mutagens) yet straightforward.  You can fast travel to and from sign posts after you've discovered them, though traveling by horse is efficient as well.  There are several open zones to explore, and they are massive and packed full of points of interest and beautiful scenery.

Animations, lip-sync, and voice acting are all top notch.  The contextual music is moody and entertaining.  Sound effects are varied and immersive.

I highly recommend Witcher 3: Wild Hunt, especially if you like action, role-playing, open-world, and great stories.  It's clear that every aspect of this game has been carefully developed and optimized to produce a high quality product.  A glossary full of useful information will help newcomers understand the world and lore a little better, but if you've read the books and played the previous games you'll notice and appreciate many more intricate details throughout.

The beautiful world is very large and populated with tons of interesting characters.  The majority of the time I find myself exploring this vast environment on horseback and stumbling across nests of monsters or hidden treasures, rather than questing.  When I am not exploring I find myself constantly challenging NPC's to Gwent, a very addicting collectible card game along the lines of Hearthstone.

The story is very interesting and really draws you in right from the start.  The side quests range from really challenging, such as monster hunts, to really amusing, such as searching for a man's lost goat.

My only complaint with this game is the controls, they are pretty ♥♥♥.  They combat will take a lot of getting used to for most people.

I feel like Iv'e barely scratched the surface of this game.  I would recommend it for any fan of RPG's.

reviewText:
I loved the Witcher when it came out - I wasn't so in love that I would have called it one of my top 10 games of all time, but I loved it.  The Witcher II absolutely knocked the first game out of the water.  It solidly broke into my top 10 games list.  My anticipation for the Witcher III was through the roof.  The game does not disappoint.  I didn't think it possible, but the Witcher III far surpasses the Witcher II.  Right now I'm even suffering from Skyrim syndrome - I've played almost 50 hours of the game, and haven't advanced the main plot very far at all.
The combat is excellent, I like the leveling system a lot as well, the voice acting is superb, the game is visually stunning, gwent is the best side-game in a game since blitzball in FFX and, of course, the game is extremely immersive.  This is especially true if you have played the previous games and/or have read any of the books.

I also heard a begger deliver the monty python leper sketch in the game. 10/10

reviewText:
Where oh where to begin.

This game has been the most anticipated title for the last 6 months, and it delivers with interest.

The story is excellent, but I do have to put a caviot in there. See, The Wild Hunt is less a sequel to the previous Witcher games as it is to the Witcher books. I, for one, have thusfar greatly enjoyed it, but I have read the books. The Wild Hunt basically assumes that you have played the last 2 games, read all the books, and remember minor characters like Dijkstra, Crach an Crate, and Kiera Metz. This is manna from the heavens to Witcher fanboys like me, but I think it alienates potential players who aren't already initiated. My suggestion is that you play the first 2 games, read the books, then play Wild Hunt.

The world is wonderfully constructed. For the first time, I actually feel like I am walking around in the world of the Witcher. The story is also written in Sapkowski's style, mixing borderline Grimdark with his signature caustic wit (something the last 2 games forgot about and is a welcome breath of fresh air in the third installment) One thing that bugs me, for all their attention to detail in referencing events and people in the books, they seem to have carefully avoided mentioning the actual reason that so many factions want Ciri, writing it off with a simple because of her Elder Blood" I have a feeling this was done to avoid freaking out American audiences with the topics of incest

reviewText:
Started out with kind of bad impressions - the movement and combat didn't feel right after having played a few hundred hours of Bloodborne.

After having played some hours into W3, though, I can safely say you really do get used to it.  And I grew to love it.  There is so much more to this game that makes up for whatever is lacking in the movement mechanics that you won't even be thinking about it before long.

The quests are amazing - even the sidequests seem well thought out.

Some standouts:  Story, graphics, voice acting, alchemy, combat (never thought I'd say that), and sidequests.

Whole heartedly recommend this to anyone who likes RPGs (or action/adventure games), and it's a serious contender for GOTY.

reviewText:
Never played the previous Witcher games? Or, like me, just have them chilling in your games list unplayed? DOESN'T MATTER!

This is one of the best games I've ever played. This is a game that can actually call itself 'next-gen' because it's miles beyond what passes for it lately. It stands on its own as a remarkable experience.

The graphics are technically great, but the art direction is fantastic. The world is truly alive and sprawling, just begging to be explored. The minimum requirements are a little more demanding than they should be, if you don't quite have what it calls for there's a good chance it will still be very playable. If you do have a nice shiny new GPU, this is the eye candy you've been waiting to throw at it.

Even only being vaguely familiar with the Witcher universe, this game quickly engrosses you into the world, the lore, the characters, and the perfectly knit gameplay that makes you feel an active part of it. Without losing the cinematic level of quality.

The combat is well balanced. This is no button masher, but it's not complicated either. Higher difficulty levels actually require attention and planning to make it through. Enemies are not forgiving, and rushing anywhere unprepared will be met with a very quick lesson on what not to do.

The story is enormous, yet fully voice casted with attention to making every single line of dialog be well delivered and acted. I can't imagine how they did it without being a narrow on-rails game. This thing is huge and intricate, with everything being of substance. There are no useless fetch quests, everything is rich and detailed!

I think you get the idea, it's incredible, and you don't need any previous experience with the series. I'm ending this here because I need to go back to playing.

tl;dr  Projected on a wall at 60fps, it's like being inside a fantasy world.

reviewText:
Having Played 50 hours of this amazing game, I feel I'm nowhere near writing a full review, but I'll do it anyway.

As an opening statement, I've read all the books (translated) played 11 hours of Witcher 1, and completed Witcher 2 so i'll make references back and forth.

First off, for the first 49 hours I'd been playing on low textures, because I'm an idiot and should've put them up to high/ ultra, but for the record, the game still looked amazing and I never looked at the graphics again after the Balcony scene. This is mainly because the game is so immersive, the story so detailed that frankly I was so focused on what I was doing the world passed me by, but I enjoyed exploring, finding a cave in the middle of nowhere, only to be savaged by a Golem way higher than me was very satisfying, especially when I came back levels later, studied it's attacks, learnt it's weaknesses and capitalised on them. The combat is way more enjoyable than Dark Souls for me. With Signs, Sword attacks and various potions as well as an expansive skill system, you can really create some fantastically focused builds.

Controls in combat are smooth, while out of combat, they can be a little off at times, often walking back and forth over an item before i'm able to pick it up, underwater controls were actually my biggest weakness in the game, but it's a controller game just as 2 was.

The game is vastly superior to 2 in so many ways (i'll mention this more as both differ in style over 1)

Inventory screen is vastly better, i'm not removing my items while trying to equip others and it's all round much better. Though the skill screen is annoying in that often I end up removing my mutagens by accident
Quests have consequences, both side and otherwise, heck even the random events have consequences both good and bad so it really gets you thinking at times about the potential results of your decisions. Won't mention any here because spoilers but they can really take you by surprise, often the result not occuring for hours later, heck I didn't see the result of one of my decisions until 30 hours later, and that was just a random event.

The world is massive, no I mean Massive, even Novigrad, the biggest would take a good 15 minutes around the outside (roughly), i've been lost in there so many times.

Quests are like nothing we've come to expect from RPGs recently, ALL quests are brilliantly voice acted, they have interesting storylines and you often don't feel like it's just a fetch quest, there is more intrigue, and all round you actually want to explore to find everything.

There are so many references back to the books which never fail to make me smile, Heck the entire ballad in Novigrad is a reference to the first blood The Last Wish". You can also find a compressed version within the game. The story of Ciri turning up in Kaer in a dress
date: again a reference to the book. And the "Basilisk" that was a Wyvern random event
recommended:
that was a reference to the book whilst it was actually Ciri who called the gentleman out pointing out the differences between the two creatures but it was still in the game in some form. All of that makes me respect CDPR even more for so much relation to source material as well as forging their own path. It's a fantastic mix.

Let's try to wrap this up because I'd rather not keep more of your time when you should be playing so:

Pros:

- Massively detailed world
- Combat is fun yet still hard

reviewText:
Easily one of the best games i've ever played. The open world is gorgeous, the story was stellar and the characters excellent, with great voice acting all round. There are a lot of quests, contracts, treasures and secrets to find, as well as interesting NPC's to meet and places to explore. Novigrad especially looked fantastic, as cities go. Lots of references from the books thrown in which makes it very rewarding for fans of the series. I was most impressed by the quality of a large number of the side quests, which could have easily been part of the main questline, as well as the excellent Witcher contracts, which really made you feel like a professional monster slayer.

The leveling system is deep and rewarding, giving you XP for completing quests as well as small amounts of XP for every monster you kill, so you can level up and assign points to four skill trees. Sword skills, alchemy, magic and a passive skill tree. You can't earn enough to max all of them out, so you'll have to commit to a play style that suits you best and stick with it, which offers good replayability as you try different skill sets.

In all, the amount of content on offer here is substantial and i cannot recommend The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt enough. Either watch a recap of the first 2 games online and get this one, or better yet play through the entire trilogy and you won't be disappointed.

reviewText: People don't exagerate when they claim this is one of the best games ever made. A game so huge it'll take you around 60-80h to finish main story line, and over 250h to complete. If not the best game, at least it's the best RPG I've ever played. Even better than Skyrim, I could say. But what truly matters is, I've had tons of fun playing through it. The Witcher III is one of the best games I have ever played. The story is just extremely captivating, with appealing characters ( Triss especially ). NEW EDIT: I actually found a way to extend my gameplay and I just am enjoying my new playthrough in Death March ( I was in Broken Bones before ). 20 hours in this new playthrough, I am focusing on doing all side quests and collecting Gwent cards ( looking for the 100% achievement ). If you are a bit bored or do not know what to do in The Witcher III, try doing as I did ( focusing on the side quests is a MUST, otherwise you will end up as I did: level 40 only having tons of level 10 quests )

reviewText:
People usually come here to find out if they should buy a game or not. Let me give you my two cents:
Has this game received more than 250 awards? Yes. Did I become a fan boy? No.

Have I played The witcher? Yes (at release day with all the numerous bugs). Did I like it? Yes. Did I become a fan boy? No.

Have I played Assassin of Kings (Witcher2)? Yes. Did I like it? Yes. Have I become a fanboy? No.

Have I played The Wild Hunt? Yes (HoS too). Did I like it? HELL YEAH! Have I become a fan boy? YOU BETTER BELIEVE IT!

Now, don’t expect I started running around with two kitchen knives strapped to my back, making Aard sings at people on the street. Not THAT kind of fan boy. Nor did I get a Gerald/Ciri tattoo, or traveled to beautiful Poland to ask CD Projekt for autographs (cool as they may be).

But this game offers a wicked narrative, S.U.P.E.R.B. graphics (on the proper gig, mind you), immersive gameplay, which will reward a player with hundreds of hours of fun (211.1 at the mo’, but B&W isn’t out yet).
You will manly try to ignore a tear at Geralt’s fatherly affection towards Ciri (I am the father of a daughter meself), or puff up your chest at Ciri’s antics.
Rarely will a bug throw you off balance, and even then, it will grab you by your breeches and drag you back in in a jiffy.

You came here for advice? Here it is: get the game! Get it now.
If you are short on money, wait for the sale period and get it. Buy the hell out of it.
Of course, you can be a rebel and torrent it, but then again, how will the artists who gave us this masterpiece will be able to give us another? Geddit?

Peace to all.

reviewText: I was running through Velen when I stumbled onto a house with a man hanged outside his residence. Inside the house I saw what was probably his wife, and two children, in an apparent suicide. The children laid in their beds and were covered in flower petals. I didn't see a  quest for the area, so I checked reddit. Apparently this scene disturbed others who wondered the same thing. There was no quest to figure out what happened. It was just there; open to interpretation on the events which led to their deaths. Some posts speculated, but it was soon discarded as scenery. Still I felt bad and wanted to find out why for the sake of closure. I kept searching but never found an answer.\n\nI'll probably never know why that scene was put in, but its the best example immersion I have ever witnessed in any game. It still bothers me when I think about it. Out of everything I've done in the game, helping or destorying villages and monsters, I couldn't save that family.

reviewText:
I'm going to start off by saying that I rate The Witcher 3 as one of the best games ever made, and I've been playing PC games for over 25 years so I don't make that statement lightly.

I only have one gripe with the game so I'm going to get it out of the way first, and that's that there’s a major disparity in how useful the different skills are.
As an example let's say you have a choice of three combat skills which are +5% fast attack damage, +5% strong attack damage or +2% crossbow critical chance.  The fast and strong attack options are going to be good depending on how you play, and putting points into one or the other will further sculpt your style of play down that path, so this feels organic and works well.  However because it’s a core part of witcher lore that witchers fight with swords, the crossbow does exactly f*ck all damage and is only used situationally for either bringing flying monsters back to ground, or for the limited situations where you need to fight underwater.  A crossbow attack takes about three times as long as a fast attack, and even a critical hit only does about 1/4 as much damage, so it's like going 'Oh dear what a tough decision I have, do I want the skill that turns Geralt into a 7 foot tall demi-god who eats rocks and sh*ts lightning bolts, or the one that allows him to p*ss his pants in the line for the bookstore?'

Right. Moving on to the plethora of good things I have to say about the game; the writing is absolutely top notch.  I would put it slightly behind Planescape: Torment but on par with Baldur's Gate 2, which basically means top 5 of all time.  Everything from the dialogue between the main characters to the peasants grumbling about their peasanty bullsh*t feels natural and believable, and there's excellent voice acting to back it up.  Some of the conversations between Geralt and the emperor Emhyr var Emreis (voiced by Charles Danse who played Tywin Lannister in Game of Thrones) were so good they made me jump up and down in my chair.

Witcher 3 is a huge game in terms of content and yet the quests are varied and interesting.  Rather than creating a 100 hour RPG with 80 hours worth of fetch quests CDPR have created a game where you'll genuinely feel like you’re part of the story and will consider the possible consequences before you act.

Graphically the game is stunning, and although I'm not a huge one for graphics I'm surprised by how much the painstakingly constructed animations (particularly the facial animations) contribute to the how immersive the game is.

The combat mechanics are great and from what I'm told they scale well with difficulty (I haven't played on the lower difficulties so I’m relying on second hand info).  It looks like they've used motion capture for a lot of the combat animations and it shows. If they haven’t then /mindblown.

All of these things combine to make The Witcher 3 an extremely immersive and engaging RPG and a triumph of modern game design.  I haven't been this impressed by a game since Planescape: Torment and Baldur’s Gate 2.  Do yourself a favour and play it.

reviewText:
It's difficult to fault an experience as rich as this.

The Witcher 3 is an expansive game, throwing the player into a world filled with lore, loot, a range of quests and monsters to kill.

Monster hunting is great, using the beastiary to assess the potions, bombs and oils you will need to handle the situation.

You will also be solving mysteries using your witcher senses.

While the combat may feel easier than The Witcher 2 this is because it's less frustrating and more fluid.

There's an in-depth alchemy system using herbs and monster remains, as well as detailed armour and weapon crafting.

Not to mention the entire Gwent side game.

Even for people who aren't the biggest fantasy fans I think you will enjoy this game.

I took me 80-100 hours on normal to beat the base game and the Hearts of Stone expansion is massive. With Blood and Wine to be longer (30 hours).

reviewText:
One of my favorite games of all time. Excellent devs, beautiful world design and story. Great voice acting, great graphics, great gameplay, great designed quests. Free DLC and real genuine expansion packs that add dozens of hours of gameplay.

Starting my third playthrough today and there's always something new to do and see every time.

So much replayability, patches, updates and some decent mod support (could be better.)

Either way its a superb game at a superb price.

Graphics: 9.5/10

Audio/Voice acting/Soundtrack: 9.75/10

Gameplay/Replay-ability: 9.25/10

Combat/HUD/Interfaces: 9.25/10

Story/World Design: 9.75/10

Dev support post launch: 10/10

Mod Support: 8/10 (only weak feature of the game)

Overall, I give this game a 9.5/10.

Would highly recommend to anyone remotely interested in open world RPGs.

reviewText:
This has been the best game I have ever played. This is also now my benchmark when playing a game.

The game

- is Ambitious. and they pulled it off.
- has a good storyline.
- has an adequate battle system. Might not be the best, but it is perfect for its own
- is excellent on voice overs. I never get tired of all those accents and Geralt's boring voice.
- has the best DLC's. Good free DLC. Hearts of Stone DLC is just superb.
- is wide! I can't stop the complentionist in me to get to all those question marks even though I finished the game.

Some notes:
- I feel the movement is a little bit clunky. I don't know if it's by design but I can say it's not smooth. Even with the alternative movement setting, I just feel it can do better.
- I'm not really sure about this but the UI seems a bit slow (30fps ish). I don't know what a 60fps UI feels like but when you play the game then hit that start button to open up inventories, maps or quest, it just doesn't feel right to me.
- Crafting system could be better. Since it's a world with too many items, it's just hard to find the components you need using the UI.

I strongly recommend that you buy this game. Sale or not.

reviewText:
This game is a masterpiece, it's not perfect that's true but almost, I mean, yeah It has some bugs like bald Geralt, or the headshots hitbox but... Those are few little mistakes for a BIG game like this. In the other hand those awesome quests and challenging bosses are going to make you forget the bugs, the quests are so interesing not just the main but the contracts and the side quests, and if you bought the expansion pass those two are interesing as the base game itself. There's always something to do, getting some Gwent cards, killing some monsters, chilling around with some women or trying to find Ciri, I don't know how someone can get bored from playing this.

The art is beautiful, in general the game looks so good plus The witcher universe is fascinating so warning, If you like good RPGs and challenging combat be careful, this game is going to absorb your life, specially that new game + option when you're done but have some achievements missing.

Hope this was helpful and thanks CD projekt red for this amazing game, you guys have made many advances if we compare the other two games with this one. Great job, cyberpunk 2077 hype is real.

reviewText:
You know how every now and then there is a game that defines a specific genre? Well, this is one of them.

This is what games should be. You think the price is too high? For the quality and amount of content you get, the price should easily be triple. Witcher 3 has only one focus as a game, and that is quality. This you can see in every aspect of the game. You will stop to listen to every dialog, you will stop to admire the scenery and you will stop to think and feel as the game challenges you emotionally. This is a complete experience, and the dedication of this company for its game is all too clear.

This is how you do a damn game, this should be the industry standard. Nothing in this game feels like just another checklist feature, or a paper/cardboard feature.

Compared to what I think is its main competitor, the game follows the already set in standard. Dragon Age Origins was a good game, while Witcher 1 was decent. Dragon Age II was a shallow game while Witcher 2 was a good game. Now Dragon Age Inquisition is an empty single player ♥♥♥♥♥♥me, while Witcher 3 is a masterpiece.

10/10 Would cry again after helping the Red Baron deal with you know who, by doing you know what.

reviewText:
Is the game good? Is it immersive? Does the game live up to the GOTY? Is it properly optimized? Is it a work of art? Is it everything it I want it to be? Will it cure my chronic passiveness? NO, not the last one.

The game is god. So many beautiful experiences are packed so tightly, I have never had my mouth open in awe so often in any other game, at all. Altogether a full on beautiful experience and a beautiful finish at the top for the Witcher series, my absolute favourite as far as series go.

Nothing has come close to this experience yet after so long after so many months. Graphics are godlike, sounds are godlike, songs and immersion is godlike. The combat system and controls were a little crappy until the devs fixed it, it was after I finished the game. Most infuriating part was Roach deciding to socialize with a whole pack of high level wolves, then walking into a tree as I try to steer him out of there, then chickening out and throwing me off. Instakill. Fu Roach.

Anyways that is fixed now. And PROPS to the devs as they still were fixing minor bugs months and months after release. I'm talking about 13 page minor bugfix notes. I have never seen any other big name dev do something so awesome after they sold the game. And they lowered the price a lot and it wasnt that high to begin with. With the Fallout 4 crap hitting the market at double the price for an insanely buggy and very poorly optimized game which still didnt get 1 non-beta fix after months of being on the market, I am very happy CDPR got the goty for TW3. I hope they show an example to other big names a little.

What else. Play it. You wont find an experience as good and refined anywhere else, not yet. Probably not for another half a year I think. Cheers^^

reviewText:
If you like RPGs, even just a little bit, then you have to play this game.
CDProjektRed have created something very, very special here.  It's obvious from the outset that so much care, thought and love have been poured into this game. Everything comes together to create something spectacular. The writing, the tone, the quest design, the art direction, the visuals etc etc are all top notch. Special mention needs to made of the seamless world. Such a small touch that has a huge impact on gameplay. You can walk from the countryside on one side of the map, go through a village, cross a bridge into a city and enter a tavern without encountering a single loading screen at all.
Even the negatives, such as the inventory system which needs a serious overhaul, don't detract from the overall experience. They become minor blemishes which you will put up with (until they are overhauled or modded) because the game is just that damn good.
This game may just be the best game ever.

Read the novels, play the first games - Geralt of Rivia's final adventure will be that much more powerful if you do.

Hands down, at least story-wise, it's the best RPG series of all times IMO.

reviewText:
Common Concerns Review
Didn't this game look better during development?  Yes.
Doesn't that mean it looks terrible now?  No.
But isn't it a console port?  Are you asking if they released a different Witcher 3 game for console and PC?
So, how does it look then?  Fantastic. Beautiful. Breathtaking. Detailed.
Don't you need two Titans to run this game on Ultra?  No. My GTX 780 works fine on Ultra.
Isn't the game poorly optimized?  At 1080p on Ultra with a steady 60 frames, I wouldn't say so. My rig struggled to do the same with other recent AAA titles.
But what about the crashes?  Update your drivers and make sure to grab the day-one patch. Most of the complaints were made before the 30 MB update.

Alright, so how's the story?  Do you like Game of Thrones?
Combat?  It's hard. Really hard.
I heard the combat was terrible.  It's a matter of opinion. You have to be careful. If you're used to button-mashing then you probably won't enjoy this game.
Others say the controls are terrible on PC.  Try a controller. My rule of thumb: if it's third-person it's better with a controller. Mouse-and-keyboard is for first-person.

If you don't enjoy this game, it isn't the game's fault. The Witcher 3 still resonates with the hardcore RPG crowd. If you didn't enjoy the other two Witcher games, there's likely nothing here that will make you enjoy this one.

reviewText:
If you like RPGs, even just a little bit, then you have to play this game.
CDProjektRed have created something very, very special here.  It's obvious from the outset that so much care, thought and love have been poured into this game. Everything comes together to create something spectacular. The writing, the tone, the quest design, the art direction, the visuals etc etc are all top notch. Special mention needs to made of the seamless world. Such a small touch that has a huge impact on gameplay. You can walk from the countryside on one side of the map, go through a village, cross a bridge into a city and enter a tavern without encountering a single loading screen at all.
Even the negatives, such as the inventory system which needs a serious overhaul, don't detract from the overall experience. They become minor blemishes which you will put up with (until they are overhauled or modded) because the game is just that damn good.
This game may just be the best game ever.

reviewText:
THE WITCHER 3: WILD HUNT REVIEW
The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt   review I had previously, went into too much unnecessary details. The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt was easily the highlight of gaming in 2015 for me. For one the amount of endless hours I spent playing this masterfully crafted piece of art is undoubtly alot, the real question is if I regret it and no, I enjoyed every second that I spent on the game.

It has some of the best graphics that a PC game has to offer. It also delivers an experience that can last up to 200+ hours of gameplay/story. One of the biggest immersive, yet breathtaking open-worlds to grace 2015.

So much f*cking quests and side-quests it's unbelievable. The characters and world design are amazing and really captures the feel of the game completely, with tons of characters that are extremely likable.

It has an amazing perk system and the signs are very fun to use to get the upperhand on the opponents in battle. The combat on the really high difficulties can be insanely fun, it forces you to learn the enemy's attacks and attack patterns while dodging at precise times to overcome each enemy and it makes you feel like a badass.

Speaking of badass, Geralt of Rivia while not being the most intriguing character on the surface is a complete and utter badass, capable of getting all the puh a man, no a witcher can possibly need.

2015'S GREATEST PORN SIMULATOR. 10/10

The game is god. So many beautiful experiences are packed so tightly, I have never had my mouth open in awe so often in any other game, at all. Altogether a full on beautiful experience and a beautiful finish at the top for the Witcher series, my absolute favourite as far as series go.

The combat system and controls were a little crappy until the devs fixed it, it was after I finished the game. Most infuriating part was Roach deciding to socialize with a whole pack of high level wolves, then walking into a tree as I try to steer him out of there, then chickening out and throwing me off. Instakill. Fu Roach.

Anyways that is fixed now. And PROPS to the devs as they still were fixing minor bugs months and months after release. I'm talking about 13 page minor bugfix notes. I have never seen any other big name dev do something so awesome after they sold the game. And they lowered the price a lot and it wasnt that high to begin with. What else. Play it. You wont find an experience as good and refined anywhere else, not yet. Probably not for another half a year I think. Cheers^^

reviewText:
A FITTING END FOR THE TALE OF THE WHITE WOLFReview - The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt

Role-playing games have always been one of the most engrossing game genres this past years. With Dragon Age Inquisition taking 2014's Game of the Year. This year another RPG game takes the crown in the name of The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt. A lot of RPG games have very great stories and presentations but no other game redefines the genre itself than The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt.

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is a massively open-world, action RPG game. Following the events of The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings, the player once again takes the role of Geralt of Rivia. With his memories restored, Geralt now begins his search for his lover, Yennefer of Vengenburg. Their reunion would then lead to another search but this time, they'll be looking for the Child of Prophecy, Ciri. But finding Ciri is not the only thing the witcher should worry about as The Wild Hunt itself is also in pursuit of her.

PRESENTATION - GRAPHICS: 10/10 MUSIC/SOUNDTRACK: 10/10
The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt features a massive open world that removing the HUD can actually get you lost in a few minutes. The game's world is so engrossing that just following the main roads isn't enough. Drifting away from the main path is tempting especially for those who love to explore, as the game offers a lot of things to be discovered whether it's a bandit camp, a nest of monsters or better yet, some hidden treasures. The game also features a day and night cycle that largely affects not just how much can Geralt see through the dark but also some quests that requires to be done at at a certain point of the day.

Like the first 2 witcher games, The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt brings back its traditional way of having conversations with NPCs and other important characters. Some of them, however, requires the player to make a choice quickly as there will be certain points in the game that responses will have time limits. The game has very much improved on this part as compared to The Witcher 2 because the characters now show more emotion whenever they deliver their dialogues and how they react to what you have to say. It has also improved the game's graphics adapting a more brighter and more lively appearance compared to The Witcher 2's dark and serious graphics.

STORY - 9.5/10
The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt's story is weaker compared to what The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings has offered. But what pulls The Witcher 3 apart from other RPG games is the content of its sidequests. The Witcher 3 has a lot of sidequests scattered across the world map and each sidequest will always have a story of its own and a grueling decision for players to make. As how Witcher games go, being a hero is not always the answer and sometimes you have to choose well which is the lesser evil. The way The Witcher 3 challenges players to make difficult choices is one of its strong points as each choice carries its own consequence that may somehow affect other quests. The Witcher 3 has redefined what a sidequest really means to a game and that not only the main quest should have a solid storyline. After all, it's the sidequests that actually let's you know more of the game's world.

GAMEPLAY - 10/10
The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt has also improved the game's combat system making it more fluid and elegant. A lot of players complain about the game's combat system but they somehow fail to see that this is an RPG game and you are playing as a witcher and not a swordsman who just hacks and slashes though everything. The combat system adapts to a witcher's fighting style. Monster battles are very unique in The Witcher 3 as there will be times that you need to prepare first before going for the kill as there are certain monsters that require you to use oils on your blades and drink potions and decoctions for additional status affects. The game's world is very unforgiving because even if you have a very high level, the player will still be prone to death whether they battle a low level monster or not. Despite such, the game doesn't prevent players from great challenges. Quests are labeled with what recommended level should the player pursue each one but you are still allowed to take it even if you're a lot of levels below the recommended level though a skull mark on a quest means certain death.

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt also features a skill tree that will depend on what the player's preferred fighting style is. Whether you fight more with your blades or with signs or both depends upon the character build you make. The game also features fast travel points but with how unpredictable the The Witcher 3's world is, I somehow rarely used it since there are a lot of surprise/sudden events that occur in towns or on the road.

I already finished the main game for over 100 hours yet there are still tons of things to do. Aside from hunting monsters, there are also treasure hunts that can help you acquire better and stronger witcher gears. There are also fist fights and horse racing but my favorite one is the Gwent card minigame. What's more is that upcoming expansions will then add more content into the game though it'll be not relevant to the main questline.

PROS:
+ Great graphics
+ Great soundtrack/Voice acting
+ Sidequests are full of content
+ Choices matter
+ Beard growth

CONS:
- Some minor open world bugs
- Weak main story


OVERALL - 9.8/10
The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is a MUST play. If you're looking for a game that's full of story content then look no further. I recommend this game to those who enjoy open-world/action/RPG games and to big Witcher fans out there. Whether you choose to romance Yennefer or Triss or both, The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is no doubt one of the best games in 2015!

reviewText:
The best way to embrace the true greatness of this game is to look how the series has improved since the first and second part of The Witcher. You simply won't find anything that hasn't change for the better.

- Vast open world that IS NOT randomly created and filled with dull stuff,
- Story, which engages you from the first 10 minutes to the very end,
- Graphics, even despite the whole controversy of a thing called downgrade, still makes from this game THE BEST LOOKING RPG ever created,
- Soundtrack, it finally goes back to the style presented originally in The Witcher 1, something what makes you forget that's just the video game, it gives you the felling you are in there, in some village , city or that you are fighting with someone / something, which makes from every single battle - an unforgettable thing,
- Every single side quest, and believe me there is A LOT of them, is actually a little story that keeps you playing with the same force as the main quests - I call it - a new quality in RPGs,
- Choices and their impact on the story - even a small choice that seems insignificant at the time can wage on the whole world around you,
- THIS GAME IS MATURE, finally something dealing with a lot of subjects which are usually handled very childish or not at all,
- Combat - nothing more to add, it's decent, though it's nothing to be praised really, you won't be able to mash buttons and win - you have to dodge, use signs, and on higher difficulties get yourself ready to have an oil for a specific enemy and a bomb to put an end to his misery.

The Witcher 3 is not a game without its flaws, although nothing that can't be fixed - some balance issues, economy basically showing Geralt as a very wealth person (which he should not be), small performance problems like stuttering in Novigrad and in my opinion very limited after the end content. Many of the things I struggled with had been already fixed and there is no need to disclose them.

All in all one of the best games in the last few years (even a decade).

reviewText:
Alright, so, this game has become one of my favorites of all time, if not THE favorite of all time, after my first playthrough. I'm going to see how well it holds up after completing it, soon. So, let's begin the list of reasons why I love this game.

1) It sticks to the key points in the story it originated from.
I read the books first, before i ever played this game, and there is no describing how happy it makes me when the characters are chatting and they bring up the story of Dandilion and the Djinn from The Last Wish. I wont go any further into it because additional tidbits involve semi-spoilers, but if you read the books, the game is that much more wonderful.
Conversely, you by no means have to have read the books, or even played the previous games, to understand what's going on in this one. Sure, it helps for background stuff, but you'll still understand everything going on at all times, (except maybe the unicorn) so dont let that stop you from this amazing experience.

2) The story itself is wonderful, in my opinion. The level of depth and detail to each character is so amazingly well done to the point where you can get reads of their opinions from the body language during a dialog scene, and you almost always have the ability to steer the conversation how you want it to go, defuse a situation or make it worse, start a blood fued or end one, etc etc.. The voice acting, too, is quite spectacular, and characters lips and faces are some of the most expressive I've seen to date.
There is one part in the story, for instance, where you listen a lady sing (she's part of a performing group) and it is hands down the best singing I've heard from a video game ever. As someone who went to an internationally acclaimed school of music for his voice, it was a fantastic experience.

reviewText:
Literally one of the best RPG's you'll ever play. Huge maps, satisfying difficulty, lore, gameplay and story. Haven't had a single moment where I felt bored. So many quests to take and each one has a relatively unique story and doesn't feel like filler just for the sake of having content. They're thought out and each have their own story. There are currently a few bugs I frequently notice:
- Game freezes at inventory screen; seems to be fixed if you turn off FPS limiter
- Nvidia hairworks lags like mad; just turn it off completely really.
- NPC's (in particular, filler peasants / guards) will appear literally right infront of you sometimes, a bit immersion breaking.
- Sometimes mouse input is ignored. If attack button isn't working in combat, hit Q to cast a sign and it should fix it.
- Softlock can sometimes be a bit awkward, as well as when the game determines you're in combat or not.
- Not a bug, but horse movement is a bit poor at times.

reviewText:
This review is purely subjective based on my hardware, a driver issue, or the game itself and may not apply to everyone and may change with the release of new drivers or future patch to the game.

The story, the characters and the enemies are the reason i'm playing this game.  The game looks great in 1080p except I won't be blown away till i see it in 4K SLI.  The more time I invest in this game using a Keyboard and Mouse though,  the more apparent it becomes that this game was intended for a Controller, which I have no real problem with being a free roaming RPG.  However, when the game presents bugs that won't let me make choices using the keyboard (fast travel, selecting cards within the card game) but it WILL let me use my controller, it becomes an issue.  The crafting system has also been revamped, a change i'm not too fond of compared to the first two Witcher titles, however restocking has never been easier once a consumable has been crafted.

That being said I am excited to play to the end which is saying alot more than any of the dozens of other games i've purchased and have barely touched. The pro's of good story telling and interesting characters outweigh the con's.  The bugs I can deal with. I'm excited to learn more about the Wild Hunt and explore a large world map.

reviewText: When I first recommended this game, it was a positive reccomendation, but I had a pretty big list of complaints that were mostly menu-related about things I didn't like. But since it released the game has received the amount of support that I expected from CD Projekt Red, and when I went to edit the review they had changed so much that I figured I'd save time by just rewriting it. Overall The Witcher 3 is easily one of the best RPGs I've played in years, if not the best, and it improves over the previous games in almost every way. There are still a few minor annoyances like the new XP system and the quest menu, but they aren't enough for me to consider them anything that would turn someone away from the game.\n\nI'd still definitely recommend playing the first two games first if you're new to the series, both because the game features a lot of returning characters from both games and because the main storyline builds on things that are only loosely explained in 3 and detailed more in the first two games, so while it's possible to enjoy the game on its own, you'll get a lot more out of it from playing the whole series even if you have to force yourself to finish the first game (which a lot of people seem to not like). It's worth buying either way, and since it's still getting active support and there are still a few free DLCs left on the release schedule (along with two expansions coming later on) it's probably only going to get better.

reviewText: An incredibly large open world RPG which draws you in and doesn't let go. An RPG which gives flavor and depth to all of its quests with brilliant writing and characters that are actually human. The world itself is incredibly gorgeous and detailed, from the trees to the swamps to the cities. The combat system is as deep or shallow as you want it to be, and you have the option of wanting to play the game as a master swordsman, a powerful mage, a cautious alchemist, or any combination of the three. Geralt of Rivia is a far better fleshed out protagonist than most RPG heroes, with his own backstory, unique skills and abilities, and philosophy, certainly no audience stand in here. I've beaten this game once already and can't wait til I have the time to enjoy it properly a second time around. This isn't just my vote for Game of the Year of 2015, but it is also possibly my favorite game I have ever played.

reviewText:
The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt review:

I've never been a large fan of the previous Witcher titles, I've only played the 2nd one partly through. The story always seemed good in those games but I found many other areas lacking, so I never gave them much of a shot. Come May this year after seeing quite a few impressive gameplay vids and reading all the positive changes Witcher 3 had compared to it's predecessors I decided to give it a go. All I can say is it does not disappoint in the slightest.

I find myself immersed into the world of Witcher 3 unlike very few games have ever accomplished in the past. The comparison of this game to Elder Scrolls: Skyrim is one even I myself have done and discussed with many other gamers I know who were on the fence about this title. Very few games have accomplished amazing graphics, story, combat, ui, crafting, character development, exploration, questing, etc. all within one game. The norm has become focussing on a few of those areas and lacking in the rest. The Witcher 3 has hit all of those marks and more for me, I've not enjoyed an rpg this much since the launch of Skyrim.

I'd recommend this game to any gamer, whether casual or hardcore as you can loose yourself into it just as much in 30 mins of play as you can in 3 hours. I went from barely giving Witcher games a thought to becoming a new fan that will follow whatever this IP comes up with in the future due to this game. I'm a hardcore pvp gamer who rarely finds the time to or has the patience to do pve or enjoy stories, yet I can't get enough of this game and haven't played another game since it's release, nor do I plan to for weeks to come. This is just further evidence at how well done this game is, in the end after over 15 years of hardcore gaming (hundreds of games) this game has become my number 3 favorite rpg of all time following Kotor 1, and very closely behind Skyrim.

Thanks for reading and best of luck in your adventures,
- Alomar (hooked)

reviewText: The Witcher 3 is a dark and twisted universe but in a good way. The kind of good way that there are not many other games with similar atmosphere and feel. The game has a solidly fun but not overly polished combat system, even still it manages to stay interesting for a very long time because the difficulty varies due to the vast array of different enemies you can face and their strengths and weaknesses. The game has a story albeit a fairly uninteresting one since the game universe is not that old and lore full yet, it's the smaller stories that are more interesting, the ones of side quests given by local peasants in their small villages that are more fun and interesting than the main story. Although the game manages to keep fresh and interesting for a very long time during your playthrough, the game does have a number of flaws. For instance the controls sometimes bug out and do something else than you want. And there is no animation for eating food in your inventory. Mostly minor things like that. All in all, it's a great, fun and interesting game that manages to surprise even me, but it's still a ways from perfect.

reviewText:
I'll begin by saying that I didn't particularly like Witcher 2, felt the story was shoddy and ended too abruptly, so I wasn't expecting that Witcher 3 would be anything incredible. I expected a game with a decent amount of content and a polished presentation.

However, by the end of my 150 hour playthrough, likely the first of many, I was convinced that Witcher 3 is one of the best games I've ever played. A masterpiece.

Superficial stuff first, this game is gorgeous. Have to stop myself from taking too many screenshots. Wind, rain and other weather clearly all have an effect on the environment. Trees sway in windy conditions and everything looks appropriately wet in a storm. I'm not running it on ultra either and it's definitely one of the prettiest games out there.

The music is fitting of each area. The murky swamps of Velen get somber string tracks that fit the feel of the area's subplot, while Novigrad and its surrounding areas get city-appropriate music. None of it is annoying or hard to listen to, just adds to the mood of the stories that the game tells.

The game's massive amount of content and massive world blew me away. Witcher 2 was set in very beautiful, atmospheric, but small environments. Witcher 3, like its predecessor, remains beautiful and atmospheric, but it's also huge.

The gameplay is notably similar to Witcher 2, and I have little problem with this. Leveling system isn't perfect but it's not a bad design. Finding new gear, armor, weapons, etc is all still quite enjoyable. Just what you'd expect from an RPG. Plenty of replayability, multiple ways to play it, etc -- you get the idea.

Oh, yeah, there's also Gwent. Gwent is ♥♥♥♥ing awesome.

While a lot of the explorable places of interest and caves are repetitive and not as involved as a dungeon in an Elder Scrolls game, the size of the world itself easily rivals an Oblivion or Skyrim. I expected an open world, but never one of this scale.

The game is absolutely filled with quests, contracts, and treasure hunts which, perhaps excluding the treasure hunts, all have great writing. Quests I expected to be simple and straightforward proved instead to be complex moral dilemmas.

I was impressed after the first few quests that did this, but this game is consistent, and throughout the game you'll be confronted with meaningful choices and stories that will challenge you to think. I have never seen a game of this scale and size that has such consistently good writing in the stories it tells. An incredible accomplishment.

Even witcher contracts are given more intrigue and suspense by the 'Aragorn-style' witcher senses mode they added where you reconstruct crimes, whereabouts of others, and the prey you're hunting. It's not huge, but it definitely adds a dimension to the gameplay and makes sense given Geralt's occupation.

*SOME VAGUE SPOILERS AHEAD*

The story is, like the rest of the quests and stories, phenomenal, with a couple missteps (also super long, guessing 50-60 hours). Unlike Witcher 2's conspiracy-ridden narrative, (which switched frequently between chasing Letho and uncovering someone else's dumb plot to do this or that) Witcher 3 wisely decides to, early on, give the player a clear motivation -- a compelling and personal motivation for Geralt. It's an easy and effective way for the writers to get the player invested in both Geralt and Ciri's stories.

(While I'm no crazy feminist, I thought it also worth mentioning that both Cerys and Ciri proved intelligent, strong-willed and multifaceted female characters. Writers did a good job with pretty much all the characters)

The more personal/focus on finding Ciri part of the story lasts from the end of the prologue to the end of the player's time in Skellige. Given how long this part (Act 1) of the game is, I had thought the story would end with finding her.

These initial 30-40 hours involve retracing Ciri's footsteps, learning about how she's changed, and why the Wild Hunt is after her. In order to retrace her steps, you'll have to, as you would expect in an RPG, do favors for others. This would be bad were they fetchquests, but each set of chores you're forced to do before finding out about Ciri's story ultimately proves a meaningful and compelling subplot of it's own.

In acts 2-3 of the game, the player finds Ciri. Ciri, Geralt, and their allies bring the conflict with the Wild Hunt to a head, among numerous other conflicts. A lot of this part involves how other characters want control of Ciri and her powers, the player's decisions in how they interact with Ciri, what Ciri's destiny is, and the end of the world.

This is to say that the story quickly shifts from a very personal, emotionally-driven narrative in act 1 to a very broad, complex, and fast-paced narrative in acts 2-3. The game warns you of this change indirectly and the demarcation between the two is pretty obvious.

I expected the narrative, having lost its focus on retracing Ciri's footsteps and learning her story, would spiral out of control trying to juggle so many characters, subplots, and themes at once.

Remarkably, it didn't spiral out of control at all. Everything comes to a clear and satisfying end and most of the events are given appropriate foreshadowing and buildup. The 'White Frost' could've used a bit more explanation and exposition -- why is it happening, why does it exist, etc. However, for the most part, the ending of the game is handled well.

Of course, I just mean everything leading up to the ending, the actual ending depends on the decisions you made -- and those have huge effects.

Not a perfect narrative, but a very strong, compelling and long one, and most games make so many missteps in their narratives that Witcher 3's is definitely exceptional.

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is exceptional in so many ways that calling it anything but a masterpiece would be a great disservice to it.

reviewText:
The best open world RPG since Skyrim.

It's even better than Skyrim in my opinion. Will take at least 100 hours of play time to complete everything. Lots of cutscenes where you control the dialogue. Your choices in these cutscenes literally change the course of the game which leads to nearly countless replay opportunities.

The world and everything in it is beautiful. High quality textures, lighting, etc. Best looking game of this sort I've ever played. I run the game with a GTX 770 and AMD 8350, 16 GB RAM and get a constant 50+ FPS.

Crafting, side quests, collecting, mini games, it literally has everything. Not to mention all the free DLC. This developer made one of the best games of all time with Witcher 3.

The only thing missing IMO would be something similar to the Hearthfire DLC in Skyrim where you could build/customize your own home to display your trophies and other collectibles. It is not necessary though and I fully enjoyed the game without this.

DEFINATELY NOT FOR CHILDREN. IF YOU ARE A PARENT BUYING THIS I WOULD RECOMEND 14 AND UP. (LANGUAGE, VIOLENCE, NUDITY, ETC)
